pros: Nothing. They don’t provide anything to help caregivers.

They frequently send caregivers to shifts that are 1+ hours away and do not compensate for gas mileage (even though they say they will.) They will work there caregivers to death with 12 hour overnight shifts, 4 times in a row, and then immediately cancel all shifts for the next couple of weeks, so they don’t have to provide benefits to their employees. They are a horrible company that is for profit, they take advantage of the elderly and sick and treat their caregivers horribly. They put caregivers in horrible and unsafe homes and then not warn us. We’re caregivers, not nurses, so we aren’t trained to be dealing with these unsafe homes and diseases and we can’t afford the proper protective gear in order to safely work. Avoid this company at all costs.

job_title: Home Health Aide in New York, NY
pros: They were the best in the industry. From our view point, agency has everything at hand to be the best again. It will take a whole village. Our sister agency, the Visiting Nurse Service of New York included.
cons:
Medicaid cuts really hurting everybody. Co-worker HHAs doing whatever it takes to hold on to long hour cases not helping anybody either. We know the heat that comes with telling truth about how hard cases can be with aggressive family members/clients and corners cut to keep cases cheap, but holding on instead of reaching out make matters worse. Communication via phone has been on and very much off since late 2013. Better since January 2016. Be prepared to prove you asked for vacation weeks ahead. Phone conversations are not enough, machine eats faxes and whoever you show up to talk too is most likely in meeting. Text messaging is so the answer for something like this. It would be a pleasant surprise if this option is heading our way anytime soon. As to date, that choice is reserved for other members of the homecare team. Then again, we may not have been told option is already there.

Supervisors really need to tell their side of things. Had no idea about them being at work until 11:00 pm as posted on this site. When would reliefs show up when a 24 hour case is split in 4 shifts? Not all neighborhoods are created equal.

review_title: An organization that is greatly needed in the community with fantastic clinicians, but internal business is outrageous.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The mission is a good reason to work for VNSNY. If helping the less fortunate in New York through medical care is your ideal job than you will like working for VNSNY. If you believe in the mission that Lillian Wald established than you will like working at VNSNY. Also, competitive salaries are considered, and four weeks vacation time is also a plus, however, taking time off isn't necessarily encouraged in some departments.
cons: The business lines are siloed. Senior leadership does not support transparency, is often fighting amongst themselves for power or ego boosting, regarding decisions making or change management. There is a great deal of confusion about the changes coming from the top-down, and employee engagement remains poor. VNSNY does not value communications with employees, and no one includes the frontline staff appropriately or toward Magnet Status. The layoffs in 2013 and 2014 were handled poorly, with individual colleagues sitting in on lay-off discussions as if for show and it felt more like targeted firings than financial complications that caused the situation. The company has lost sight of best practices, values and mission, especially on how to treat and communicate with employees.

review_title: Great Company with a Great Mission
job_title: Director in New York, NY
pros: Great work environment, treats employees well, excellent benefits
cons: Could move faster on innovations

review_title: CTI, then CSS, different name, but same BS
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Used to be good, bonuses, salary, nice bathrooms
cons:
The people at the top are great at talking the talk, but when actual work needs to be done, it falls onto the worker bees who are not appreciated: for instance, the field clinicians will not receive bonuses this year but their managers, the ITCMs(?) will. 

Left and right, talent leaves. The newly formed education department is completely scattered, with a non-clinical so-called "project manager" (name rhymes with All) who bosses around his peers and gets away with not giving clear direction, showing a lack of leadership and organization, and completely fails to grasp of the bigger picture. These type of people get a six-figured salary, go figure!

So-called "PM" does not understand clinical aspects whatsoever, does not follow up on work, and just dumps tasks and duties with no rhyme or reason. It's difficult to tell who the real director is, even when this NOOB has the title. That person has her own clique of "talkers and complainers" who are not fit for management roles. Directives are unclear and given from too many people with conflicting messages. Heavy waste of money in certain departments, and crucial staff are cut-- volunteer department, and even field clinicians. HA.  

Completely hostile, cold culture-- HR doesn't do anything when complaints are made. People get away with bullying their peers. 

Interns are treated better than long-term employees. It's sad, really. Sinking ship.

review_title: Partners In Care (PIC), #1 homecare agency - what you see is not always what you get!
job_title: Home Health Aide in New York, NY
pros: Lots of cases.  Impressive office.
cons: Nepotism rules. Befriending supervisors determines hours offered and whether you will be sent to work in clean vs filthy conditions.  I don't always have time to empty my bag at end of shift to search for bed bugs and roaches. RNs assess and diagnose but HHAs must be prepared to take the heat for reporting filth, that client is able to do for self and issues with ambulating and transferring missed or ignored by RNs and PTs.  The city wants their cake and eat it too.  Cheaper to keep client at home even it is the most unsafe option when Medicaid declines to approve proper equipment.  The money fraud made the NY Times (our sister agency The Visiting Nurse Services of NY) but the safety issues not addressed.  PIC management made changes, but may be too late.  Unprofessional behavior to us HHAs is greenlighted by some in management, with the VNSNY stamp of approval.

job_title: Human Resources Generalist in New York, NY
pros: Fellow workers are dedicated and loyal
cons: Changing environment due to insurance fraud

review_title: Not the agency it used to be...
job_title: Public Health Nurse in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Strong mission. Benefits are good compare to competitors. Generate alot of PTO quickly. Fairly ok union. You will learn alot.
cons:
Agency is not what it used to be.  Employees that are dedicated to patients are leaving  due to poor communication between management and employees. Shortage of nurses and field staff.. Unrealistic expectations management place on field nurse (field staff) to meet productivity in area where parking is a challenge. Management tend to micromanage.  High quantity of patients assigned to you per day. Patient assigned and added to your schedule (caseload), hours after you received your assignment for the day (After 11am ).  Pay is low for this kind of stress. Computer system tends to crash or have glitches. Any issues with tablet in the morning ......Long wait time for IT staff.
Inconsistency of policies/Rules practiced throughout the agency. One region practice one thing, another doesnt. Health insurance is ok, Dental plan needs to change

job_title: Manager in New York, NY
pros: I really appreciate VNSNY's commitment to developing leadership from within the organization. I recently had the opportunity to participate in an intensive leadership development program , ACE (Achieving a Cultural of Excellence) designed for high potential managers.  ACE included excellent workshops on strategic management, executive presence, financial acumen,  coaching and delegation and a wide variety of other topics. One of the highlights of the program was access to Senior Leadership through a series of very candid  executive presentations.  At the end of the program, the participants worked on an action learning project together to address a strategic need within the organization.  On an individual level, I was matched with an internal coach  who helped me focus on my own career development plan . I also left ACE with an invaluable network of management colleagues from departments across the agency. In addition to ACE, the Organizational Development Department also offers many other interesting , shorter term programs.
cons: If you are not comfortable working in a fast paced environment where change is a given, VNSNY may not be the right match. VNSNY is always making adjustments to navigate the changing healthcare landscape.

review_title: There is a reason why Partners In Care has a high turn over rate. They aren't as great as they claim to be.
job_title: Home Health Aide in New York, NY
pros:
-This job will mainly work for you if you have open availability and don't mind working in boroughs
besides your own.

-You have little/no responsibility in your life and can deal with (as little as 2 hour cases) they may give you. 

-Great benefits.
cons:
-You go through 3 weeks of training (putting every thing aside in your life), only to officially be hired and
feel 
as if you STILL do not have a job because there are few assignments available.

-A great majority of the time it is almost impossible to reach a coordinator.
Lets just say there is an emergency situation or you are looking to be assigned to
a new case, you will spend 30 minutes on end waiting for a coordinator to answer.
If you're LUCKY by the end of the 30 minutes, they actually do answer.

-You have to constantly call Partners In Care looking for a new case.
They WILL NOT call you.

-Cases open and close within a heart beat. There will be times you have jobs, and then there will
be times you feel as if you are out of one. 
If you need stability in your life...this is NOT the job for you!

review_title: Great company has gone bad! Nurses stay away!
job_title: Registered Nurse in New York, NY
pros: The benefits are the only thing good right now but they are trying to get rid off a lot of things at each contract.
cons: For past 4 years, the company has adopted a very low morale and culture that are ruining the organization itself. The company is being run by business people instead of clinicians which is really the cause of this low morale and values. Manager became very hostile and offer no support to nurses. They harass and bully their nurses. They attempt to exploit nurses by demanding working even on days off and often demand working overtime without compensation and if nurses retaliate they are targeted. They demand 2 person's work to be done by one person in 7.25 hrs. They don't care about driving distances, parking challenges, acuity of patients, or time required for coordination. There's no life balance. On patient's side, quality care is not able to be achieved due to limited providers, increase nurses turnover rates, lack of continuity care. Patients are being promised services they never get and cases are being opened and closed without meeting their goals.

review_title: It used to be a nice place to work
job_title: Central Intake in New York, NY
pros: The company's historic and noble mission, the opportunity to learn the working of the home care side of health care, seeing some very dedicated professionals at work. Meaningful relationships built with co-workers.
cons: The new administration that has trashed the company's good name in only three years. The nepotism-some departments all go to the same church, many quickly promoted managers are sons or daughters of high level execs. The union busting-many union business staff were fired, and many union nurses replaced with scabs just out of nursing school who have no idea what they are being asked to do endangers their licenses. The lack of concern that high level management has for the patients and staff. The lack of a corporate training program. The very small training staff was fired two layoffs ago, but were saved by their powerful boss and are now in one of those jobs where no one knows exactly what they do all day. The culture that allows bullying, spying, favoritism to go on, and HR is not able or willing to stop it. They believe that only clinical degrees matter so nurses can do jobs way out of their skill sets.

review_title: A company that truly cares about its employees
job_title: Product Manager in New York, NY
pros: Company has amazing vacation policy (30 days), though only 8 holidays. But with 38 days, it is the best PTO policy of my entire career. They also allow for remote work. VNSNY tends to have flexible schedule, as long as you get the work done. The employee morale is really good and positive for the most part. You can see that employees feel appreciated. The company has multiple activities to make the employees feel taken care of. They offer a huge amount of free training for all levels of employment and it is quality training (unlike other companies I have been at). The company culture is great, with leadership constantly telling employees they are the company's biggest asset. Even just saying that is huge. They have a quarterly employee survey and employees can submit any type of feedback and it is reviewed and considered. Best place of my 20 year career.
cons: location on the east side of manhattan is a bit of a hassle

job_title: Enterprise Sales and Marketing in New York, NY
pros: Largest & oldest home care company in the country.  There was a feeling of trust between Senior Managment and the employees. We were a team with the best product, clinicians, education department, etc. We were far from perfect but everyone worked to help improve the health and well being of our customers. Everyone wanted to work for VNSNY.
cons: Lies regarding lay-offs; poor planning  & rollout for new work fliows. CEO/ President announced her resignation and was gone in 24hours.  Company loyalty is gone, many of the experienced business and clinical professionals were either let go or just left.   CHOICE almost ruined the entire company; and it's not over. The president for CHOICE is still under investigation.

job_title: Certified Home Health Aide in New York, NY
pros: Not one got dam thing is pro about this company. Very few nice people. Nope I take that back ain't none of them nice just miserable people who don't like there job just like us😩.
cons: Where do I start 🤔. A case I worked was from 9am to 2 pm. Well she got sick and I call emergency and had to go with her. I was there till midnight  no one answered the phone at the agency called all day until the doctor said she's staying. They will get you for abandonment. Wasn't working for over a month and the nurse and the agency were calling me asking me where she's at. She's not my mother what do I know. Sent me a letter saying I was out of compliance and threatened to separate of employment. Well I found a better job in Brooklyn going for my cdl. Oh they paid me my over time. But I will never work for home care ever again after over 20 something years. Toss my uniforms in the trash and didn't look back. Stay healthy people so you won't be needing home care in the future if it's like this.and if you do and it happens to be this company? Kill your self before they do. Peace out✌🏾

job_title: Support Staff in New York, NY
pros:
Pto
Fmla
Coworkers are nice
Minor tuition assistance 
Direct deposit
cons:
Can’t use pto
No work life balance
Expected to take on workload of 5 people
Not enough staff
Manager and supervisor constantly accuse staff of not being productive or not working
Supervisor constantly telling people they can leave
Company only appreciative of clinical staff
Telework is dangled like a carrot

No one you can ask questions because mgr and supervisor are never available and always start their day later than the rest of the staff.
Everything is considered unplanned pto.
There is stuff that looks like mold in the ceilings in some small areas and in general not sanitary.

job_title: Administrative in New York, NY
pros: It's a company that you can stay at for a long time and make camp there. The benefits are good and the you are reimbursed for you education. But that is it!
cons:
*You work and work and they add to your daily responsibilities, but they keep adding to your responsibilities
*You work and work but they never give you an actual raise. They have 3% yearly increases...JOKE!
*After you dedicate years of work you get fired (or what they call lay off) and if you complain or say your going to sue, you are threatened with not getting your severance pay and they may challenge your unemployment benefits. You get treated like crap!
*Management does not care about lower level employees. The top people make big money the bottom people make very little and the top management never ever leave! They are the for 30 years easily.
*They have laid off over a thousand people already from what I have heard...not a good sign under the new management
*I was there for 5 years in the main office and not once did the CEO say good morning to me unless I said something first. AMAZING!!!

job_title: Anonymous in New York, NY
pros: Has worked in Information Technology for more than 10 years.  Miss the team already! Great Team, Good People.  Lot of changes happened in past 3 years. Management took lot of new initiatives; good and bad for some individuals. Big investments were made in building new Infrastructure, Network, Support etc.  The new CIO introduced the concept of Bullpen Meetings which helped in narrowing the gap between management and staff. These meetings were held to let the team know what is happening in IT and in VNSNY, challenges the Company has and future direction of the Agency.  Open floor discussions, never seen in past.  Overall, liked the management for being honest with staff.
cons: As every challenge comes with risk, these changes helped some people in improving their skills and go with new initiatives taken by the IT Management and some people ended up loosing their jobs.  I guess in this competitive market, happens everywhere where people find better opportunities based on their skills and people loose jobs because it is hard to compete with new changes and initiatives.

job_title: Business Development in New York, NY
pros:
- The pay is similar to what other healthcare institutions pay for registered nurses (maybe a little less but comparable).
- Most of the people whom I work with are a pleasure to work with (who are on my tier of the work hierarchy)
- Benefits are on par with other healthcare oganizations
cons:
- Management has instilled a company culture of bullying and belittling their employees which stems from the top down.
- The company is vastly compartmentalized even within the same departments.
- There seems to be more management personnel than "worker bees".
- Favoritism is present and transparent in when providing career advancements.
- As a  healthcare corporation you can expect policies to change with changing tides but changes here happen  a lot more than expect and probably necessary.
- There is no education department (how can one expect to learn anything at work).
- The software used in all departments is dreadful and makes you feel as if you are playing Tetris.
- Micro-management is the norm and almost encouraged.
- Job security is a foreign concept as frequent news of entire departments being switched, terminated or given an ultimatum is common.

review_title: Too many politics, too many VPs, too many nepotism
job_title: Project Analyst in New York, NY
pros: time off and  benefits on par with industry
cons:
I have worked with a few companies but for one this size, I have never seen so many VPs, and so many obvious un-qualified people as managers and directors. 
So many consultants, they feel like they are the FTE employees! No rhyme or reason for the difference in salary -- same employee, one has x whereas the other 15K more. 
Friends advocate for their friends to get promotion. While most of the non-senior staffs receives less 2% bonus, most of the managers and above received more than 18%. How is that fair? It's just a mess. Is it a surprised the better people are leaving or have left whereas the folks with more than ten years at the company are those that are just complacent..

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Used to be the place that people loved to go to work and take pride in what they did. Great Benefits and Very few Good Managers left. Wonderful Mission to help their patients.
cons: Highly Corrupt IT senior Management, Starting from the CIO and over paid VP's that do not understand technology. Highly stressful environment due to Layoffs and impending layoffs due to Poor IT spending by CIO and partnership with vendors that DO NOT benefit VNSNY rather benefit themselves.

review_title: Used to be good. Outlook is terrible.

review_title: Too many changes and not for the better.
job_title: Home Care Consultant in New York, NY
pros:
Supportive direct management
Lots of various one day training opportunities 
Ability to move to different departments
Tuition reimbursement (1 year mandatory post-reimbursement retention)
Flexible schedule
cons:
Poor communication between senior management to staff.
During lay-offs, only emails were sent one day to a few days before actual event happening, causing resentment, disorientation and low morale at work place. 
Talks about all the reforms months in advance, but actual change is slow to come, poor training for A LOT of added work. 
Poor per-diem coverage to clinical staff pool when someone is off/sick, causing disproportional amount of work added to regular staff.
Very poor work-life balance.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: An established organization with a well-intentioned mission and a great public relations message. This gives the organization a seat at the table with any health care initiative. The organization has made attempts to turn itself around after some serious ethical missteps and poor business decisions.
cons: Make no mistake. The culture has not changed and the organization remains a collective of silos of insiders and outsiders, with no commitment of leadership, at any level, to change this perception. If you are not an insider, you will get little or no support for your initiatives. You will have to be a self-starter prepared to bring your own resources and to put in long hours and weekends with no additional compensation. If you can't effect change fast enough, you will be out. Or want out.

job_title: Program Coordinator in Bronx, NY
pros: From the moment I submitted my resume to the moment I started I felt welcomed, valued and appreciated.  Recruiter was so prompt with their response time.  The process was easy to understand and there was communication along the way.  The interview process was great as well! Made a connection with Program Manager and Director right from the start!  Since coming on board I have received so much support and see that there is consistency with the support as well.
cons: No downside that I can see.  The benefits are excellent, salary works for me and hours are perfect for my life.

review_title: This is a great company to work for, it offers a lot of benefit for RN.
job_title: RN Nurse Consultant in New York, NY
pros: This company offers good pension plan match 401k, continue education tuition reimbursement, good medical insurance plan and good vacation. They offer different shift for RN and LPNs. This company and organization was started by a woman during the Great Depression helping sick and underprivileged people in New York getting care at home.
cons: There is not enough appreciation for nurses. The field nurses are sometimes are expected to make too many visit in not enough time.

review_title: Great colleagues and interesting work for a good cause
job_title: Data Scientist in New York, NY
pros: My colleagues are very smart, friendly and collaborative. The work is interesting. There is good work-life balance. I like that it is towards a good cause that I believe in. Management in my group are all friendly, smart and hard working. As an interview candidate, they got back to me quickly (within a day or 2) after each step of the interview process. VNSNY leadership is very involved and visible; I am impressed with and inspired by the President, Marki Flannery. The main building in midtown is very nice.
cons: I don't have any cons related to the work or environment. Only note is that there is no paid maternity/paternity leave, you can use a combination of disability, NYS paid family leave, and PTO.

review_title: VNSNY has a wonderful mission and provides great care, however it is not well managed.
job_title: Manager in New York, NY
pros: VNSNY has an excellent mission to serve all who need it, and the dedicated clinical staff fulfills this mission every day and provides high quality care. Traditionally the organization has had good work life balance but in recent years that has been less true because everyone has been asked to do more with less. There are excellent vacation benefits and solid medical, dental, and other benefits.
cons: The biggest weaknesses at VNSNY are a lack of transparency in management, and a dysfunctional management culture that has many silos of all types (geography, program, payor) that inhibits decisivness. Projects drag on and change is slow and difficult.  Compensation is weaker than it should be.

review_title: Best company I've ever worked for.
job_title: Medical Social Worker in Bronx, NY
pros: In many different ways, VNSNY demonstrate that they care for their employees.  Salary is comparable and time off is above any amount of time offered out there.  Staff are the best in their field (Nursing, SW, Nutritionist, Physical Therapist, Managerial etc.)  Everyone looks out for one another - very tight community to work for.  I MISS WORKING AT VNSNY and would love to go back!!!!!!
cons: Providing homecare is NOT for everyone.  But if you enjoy working in the field this may be the job for you.

job_title: Medical Management Care Coordinator in New York, NY
pros:
Excellent benefits, starting pay, and location 34th ST
Great co-workers and team atmosphere 
You will definitely learn a lot and grow your knowledge 
Good work-life balance
cons:
High-volume of work sometimes it felt like we were just putting out fires. 
 
MMCC tends to be the catch call before the RNs. 

As enrollment grew so did the workload but not the staff luckily we had a great realistic and supportive manager who pulled help from other departments as needed.

Office moved to Brooklyn. Which lead to my resignation. Would love to return to this company but there are few remote opportunities for non-clinical staff

job_title: Social Worker in Bronx, NY
pros: Great team of people. Good clinical experience. Very good supervision and structure! They promote with in. Staff does turn over frequently, but administrative staff is solid. They offer many opportunities for Continuing Education and career advancement. The company mission is positive and in general they really do keep their focus on serving communities/clients in need.
cons: Young staff. Direct in home care with often dangerous clients. due to mental illness. Lots of commuting esp. when working on ACT Team in the Bronx. Many clients are non-compliant which makes providing services a challenge. Lots of paper work.

job_title: Mental Health Specialist in Bronx, NY
pros:
Free Metro Card 
Out in the field a lot -Flexible hours
cons:
Everything.
The organization has a great idea but did not execute it well. Supervisors were not trained and had no prior experience. You were on your own to teach and learn for your self. IF you asked for help you were looked down upon. and if you didnt ask for help you were told to "do better." This position was not a place for you to grow. It's a great job for in between but not long term. Staff were rude often times and were not sure of the position themselves. Staff were not receptive to feedback or creative ideas. 

Some staff received higher salary than others.  The turn over is SO HIGH TOO! Which is NOT a good sign for professional growth. If you're a social worker you do NOT receive license hours .
Lack of communication between supervisors and employees.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Rochester, NY
pros: I love the autonomy, flexible hours, and computerized charting. I stay busy, sometimes too busy, but it makes time go by fast.
cons: There is a lot of turnover in home care, especially in management. It makes it difficult to know who to go to when you have a problem. The caseloads are outrageous sometimes which makes effective case management nearly impossible. When this is brought to management attention we are told 'people are working on it' or 'you need to prioritize better'. These statements are neither helpful nor encouraging.

review_title: first starting out ok but get out asap

review_title: Worst Company Ever / Per Diem RN
job_title: Registered Nurse in New York, NY
pros: The nursing orientation team (which was made up of one nursing orientation manager and two orientation nurses) was extremely supportive. Without them, I would not be where I am today. Unfortunately, I heard the whole team was laid off in 2014. My coworkers (fellow nurses, speech language pathologists, social workers, and physical and occupational therapists) were easy to get along.
cons:
-Position and Salary/Work-life Balance
I was a part of VNSNY's new graduate RN program; most nurses in this program were hired as Per Diem. The rates at the time were $55 per patient; $58 on weekends and holidays; no time and a half; no OT, no benefits, no sick days. On a typical working day, I would see about 6-12 patients, and, on average, work at least 15 hours on a working day, and work at least 4-6 hours on my day off (completing charting, getting patients homecare plans figured out with HHAs, and returning MD calls). I literally never had time to see friends or family due to work. This is a common theme among all homecare nurses (full time, part time and per diem) I have met.

-Work Culture
There are a few managers (Nursing Field manager of different nursing team/areas, and the weekend/holiday managers) nurses work with. These managers are obsessed to fill quotas, if a nurse saw as many patients as possible, it was a great day for them. They do not care about quality of care for patients, it is all about quantity; and they do not see how burnt out their nurses are, nor do they care. Due to this work culture, I found myself completing unfinished work that other nurses did not have time to do. This is a toxic environment that starts with the managers that trickle down to the nurses, which ultimately leads to low quality of care for patients. Nurses are also hounded on for not completing charting on time (when a nurse is consistently working 15+ hours a day for at least 5 days a week, and have not finished charting on time, it is because they have been assigned a lot more work than they can handle). Every single nurse I have met during this time were burnt out (and some have not even worked a year at the position), and said they were not happy with their job and was planning on quitting.

-Union
I still do not understand why per diem nurses pay union dues (United Federation of Teachers union). Since orientation, union representatives always said, "Per diem nurses have no rights, only full time nurses have rights." Per diem nurses paying them to do nothing is ridiculous. When the 2013 and 2014 massive lay-offs were happening, the union was not able to do anything for their full time employees as well.

job_title: Third Party Credit Collection Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Employees are friendly.  The printer is reliable.  The bathrooms are cleaned well.  The office doesn't smell like old cheese.
cons: Everyone is miserable from the minute they walk into the door to the minute they leave.  Cutbacks are obvious when spending a day in the office, even office supplies are hard to come by when you need them.  The latest office software on my VNSNY computer is Microsoft Office 2003.  We are forced to buy K-Cups for the keurig since they do not provide coffee, but even the keurig machine has stopped working.  I doubt they try to replace it. During the summer it is insanely hot within the building, I often sweat uncontrollably.   Ridiculous communication barriers exist between different levels of the company, making it wildly difficult to accomplish simple tasks.  I have put in numerous simple requests for assistance with my computer, and they have all gone ignored.  Company systems are totally outdated, I am forced to rummage through massively disorganized filing cabinets to retrieve patient records.  Simple tasks become insanely stressful, time-consuming and frustrating processes.  There is no sense of community or teamwork within the office, everyone seems content to just look after themselves.  Additionally, managers command such minimal respect from other employees because their ability to get things done in a timely fashion is laughable.  The happiest moment of my day is when I leave the building.  Make sure you are WELL compensated if you are accepting a position within the VNSNY because you are bound to endure a miserable  time.
